description: This application is in dire need of a user interface redesign. It's very difficult to use, and some of the GPG functionality doesn't seem to work at all. Still, it's the best way I know of to access passwords that are saved in GNOME's keyring, and it lets you add new saved passwords as well.
It will frequently forget your assigned passwords to various key rings, including your login key ring.

I don't agree with the Linux communities' obsession with passwords. If we want passwords, we should add them. We shouldn't be forced to have them!

You get annoying popups telling you your keyring that you are forced to type in. I don't understand this program at all.
It's an annoying application we don't need and keeps having annoying popups.
I guess that's about it. A new interface would be nice. Also the ability to sync keys via WebDAV / Nextcloud, Google Drive, Dropbox, iCloud etc. would be nice.

Agreed with the reviewer who said the GUI needs to be redesigned, this program needs serious attention. It's not equipped to deal with the amount of passwords we use every day, and ease of use in storing and using them. It's frustrating to work with, you can't put in all the info you need for some accounts/passwords, if you want to copy a password you need to make it visible first, usw.
summary: This program was my big disappointment after switching to Gnome

description:
I can import my signature through the GUI, in the command line with gpg or gpg2... In any way I try, Seahorse does not show my sec and pub keys.
But they do exist and work, since from the command line I can use all the functionality.
Useless and buggy GUI.
No PGP key option in menu so cannot create PGP key on fedora 28

The interface provided by seahorse is very clumsy, for example deleting multiple items from the keychain takes forever as it has to be done one by one. Smartcard integration is nonexistent, yet seahorse is more than happy to prompt the user for a PIN, why? I don't know. Also, it'd be great if gnome-keyring-daemon supported ed25519 keys for ssh.
Can't say anything bad about it. Was just shocked by the negativity in the existing reviews.
summary: Simple, but does the job decently well

description: I don't understand why you need this useless bloatware I don't need extra senseless passwords I guess whatever makes the linux community have goody gum drop dreams
Should not be installed by default.

I have yet to use it, except for the creation of a key. No idea why so many people trashed it in the ratings. None. It's friggin' awesome. It also seems to be the mainstay of encryption on Ubuntu. If there's a security flaw or some advanced gripe, theoretically someone should leave a review. I am, on my end, very enthralled to have this kick-arse, free piece of arcane machinery code! It is indeed pretty darn cool. I just got through making my own key for the very first time. So, I don't know much about it, yet, but I'm giving it five stars. It is exciting to use this baby. I flat out love it so far. I have not tried yet to do anything advanced with it, as I just commenced studying it on something semi-whimsical within the preceding few hours, during which time I was admittedly mostly doing other tasks. Anyway, it's pretty cool, just look for a guide on how to use it. I am truly excited about it. Linux is awesome. This program is pretty friggin' cool, and it is free. 

Anyway, I do indeed thusly begin to digress to a greater extent than I probably can do without being passe. Not to be a dead horse to death, but, I am really excited about this "Tech." Thank you so much to whoever worked on this stuff! It is... sorry, but... it is friggin' awesome. I do not wish to be rude, but, I would encourage anyone reading this as the sole review, to strongly consider ignoring the (currently) 9 1-star ratings. I conjecture that the raters simply did not have a good time trying to figure it out. It is not quite as simple as a LibreOffice password, not remotely, but it is still ultra-sweet and totally cool. Much love and appreciation from a newbie.
so very, very buggy
Fails at importing certificates with no understandable message
I need to be able to sign documents and it just does not import my key and certificate. Have to use Windows for that, shame.
summary: Unusable and rendering Ubuntu unusable as well

description: Saved a ton of trouble when my logon password and the keyring password were not in sync. Easily deleted the old keyring and created a new one.
ed25519 support for create and import missing
A veces no reconoce las claves GPG, no las importa, y presenta ese tipo de problemas. Una lástima. Lo destacable es la extensión para el navegador nautilus: seahorse-nautilus.
summary: Da trabajo con las claves GPG

description: Ralentizando el ordenador cuando ni la he utilizado jamas
Excellente application.

SE: Ubuntu 18.04 LTS 64 bits

Fonctionne parfaitement !

В целом, хорошее приложение, но напрягает что все пароли можно посмотреть в открытом виде. Это может сделать кто угодно за вашим компьютером буквально в три клика:/ Это конечно и так можно сделать обратившись к gnome-keyring через dbus, но через seahorse это становиться слишком элементарно даже для технически неподкованного человека. Вашей девушки например!
summary: Отображает все пароли в открытом виде

description: Delete this if you don't want your passwords to be compromised, when you left your PC or Laptop for a few minutes without locking it or gave someone to use.
Rest everything is described in comments. Use with own discretion. Shortcut to hack.
summary: Not able to import PEM certificates
